text: (upbeat music)

- I'm Sarah Storelli on a
quest to discover the people

behind the cutting edge
innovations across industries

to tell the stories that
define them far more
than their titles.
My guest today is Dominic DelMolino.

Well, thanks so much for
being here today, Dominic.
Really appreciate you taking the time.
- Oh, thank you so much.
Great to be here.
- Well, let's dive in.
So my first question

for you is really who has
inspired you, maybe even the most,

you know, over the course
of your career journey?
- Yeah, like any person who's kind of gone

through a long journey, you
often have a bunch of mentors

and oftentimes you have a really
good foundation, you know,
hopefully from someone who was important
in your life early on.

So for me that those were, of
course, my parents, you know,
teaching me a lot about ways to work hard

and be curious and
really dive into things.
And then early in my career
I had a great mentor who kind of explained

to me about how do you make
the now technology real
for the customers we were working with.

And so, you know, that
inspired me to kind of think
about how I could have more of an impact
and do more of that.

And, you know, that kind
of example really set me
on my path.
- That's amazing.

Now we won't necessarily
go all the way back

to childhood per se, but
I would say, you know,

were there certain
influences from childhood

that you think did more or
less even shape your career

in the sense of really
wanting to pursue technology?

- Yeah, I think I always had
a knack for kind of science

and technology stuff and some
of that stuff fortunately,

I was fortunate for a
lot of it to come easy

to me in some ways, and
I was always impressed

with what could be done with
some kind of technology.

And so when I got my first
opportunity to experiment

with like a personal
computer, and I'm like,
"Wow, look what it can do."

And I remember other
people I would talk to

and they'd be like, "It
doesn't make sense to me.
I don't know why this is important"
or "I really don't understand it.
"It doesn't come easy to me."

And I was like, "Wow, I
really like to help people see

what they could do with
something like this."

And back then it was
real simple stuff like,
"Oh I want to catalog all my recipes
and look up what I can make with sausage."
Right?

And, you know, it'd be so easy
if you could do that quickly
instead of paging through four cookbooks
and a thing like that.

So early on it was always
about, well, I like this.
It seems easy to me.
It doesn't seem easy to everybody
so how can I make it more accessible?
How can I show people

that this is really
cool and can be useful?

So that's how I started
on kind of my journey

of going back and forth between
consulting and technology
because what's new with technology
and then how do I help people use it

has been my ethic really
throughout my career.

- You know, you mentioned how
things obviously were simpler,

you know, in in previous
times, and you know,
now we are living in a complex world.
And so do you still really, I guess,
foster that simplistic mindset, you know,
as you are thinking about, you know,

really these next
innovations that, you know,

really how has that continued
to maybe shape your reality

of embracing a more simplistic
approach even for customers?
- Yeah, and it's a great question

because I don't even like
to think of it as simplistic
as more as ubiquitous or universal.
If you think about it today
and one of the reasons I moved

from working private sector
to pub sector is, you know,

in public sector, everyone is
kind of required now to engage
with some level of technology
whether it's a government website
or an application to apply for, you know,
a scholarship or apply for a university

or going through your medical
stuff on your phone nowadays.
We all have a time when we have to engage
with technology and it's almost universal.
And so for me

how do I make that possible
for everybody, right?

A private company can choose
sometimes who they decide
to serve and who they won't.
You know, where our product is designed
for this set of customers.

But a public sector entity
doesn't have that option.

They have to make their
technology accessible
for everybody to use.

And so thinking about
accessibility, thinking

about those different dimensions
of, you know, color choices

and font choices and assistive
devices and, you know,

is it easy and accessible
for people to use?

And for me, you know,
the joy comes when it is.

And so that to me is not
necessarily making things simpler
but making it more accessible
is something I'm always energized by.
- I love that.
So that being said,

what is your favorite Amazon
leadership principle and why?
- Oh, I love that there's so many
of the leadership principles
and you can talk about a lot of them.

I think my favorite is
really customer obsession.

I love seeing the look
on a customer's face
when they realize, "Oh my gosh.
I can do that?
And it only costs this much
and it can be done that quickly?"
And you know, the joy you see

with a customer of showing
them how technology can be used

for their mission and helps
serve their end customers.

So, you know, I would
say customer obsession.

I think if you asked my
colleagues though, and the folks

who work for me, they're
gonna tell you dive deep

because they know that I
don't like to just, you know,

opine on a problem that
I haven't researched
or haven't tried to understand.

Dive deep is something I
seem to have a passion for.
- I love it.

But I think that's so
important given your role of,

you know, being this
pioneer really of, you know,
the technology industry and you know,

even to that point, you
know, gen AI, huge topic,
you know, as we all know right now,

very near and dear to all of
us, and we know especially you.
And so, you know,

what do you think really are
those even big opportunities,

you know, for our customers,
whether it is, you know,

in regards to helping
earn trust, you know,

among them or, you know,
advancing society holistically

of maybe making technology
more accessible.

I'll just be kind of curious
about those initial thoughts.
- Yeah, I'm excited by the possibility

for everyone to have this
kind of productivity boost

by having an intelligent AI
assistant that is assisting them
with all kinds of tasks.
Like, "Oh my gosh.

I gotta write an email to
ask for this kind of thing

and I don't know how to
write it in a formal way.
AI, can you help me?
I need to do these things.
Can you write it in this fashion for me?"
And you have access to that.

And so I think there's
all these wonderful ways

that generative AI can be
used as an assistive tool
for people and everyone should have access
to something like that.
So the productivity improvement,
the ability to kind of offload some work

and to get advice in a way
that that is verifiably good.
I mean, I think in many cases we're still
at the stage where we want to verify

that what generative AI
tells us is something
that's gonna be useful,
but in many cases it is.

And we're seeing lots of
productivity improvements

and benefits for people
who take advantage of it.

So for me, I think we're
just at the dawn of that.

But it is important to me from
a public sector perspective
and again, giving that customer obsession

and making the world a
better place kind of thing,

how do we make it
available for many people
to benefit from that capability?

And so that's keen and
top of mind for me a lot.
- And to that point, so I, you know,
have a similar passion and stuff.
I love tech for good.

I really think it can make
the world a better place.
Of course, there is always, you know,

it's a double-sided
coin as with everything.
You know, and so, you know,

as you continue to think of
these, you know, innovations

or diving deep into generative
AI, I guess, you know,

could you share with our
audience really, you know,
why you think, you know,

technology can be and
should be used for good?

- Yeah, I, again, I
think we would be remiss
not to take advantage, you know,
how do we help people be able

to understand problems
more quickly, get at data

that's more useful to them
quickly and not shy away

from the possibilities
that are capable there.
And we should be, you know,
transparent about how we use it too.
I think that's gonna be another area
where I've seen people say,
"Well, if you're gonna use generative AI,
it's really important to think critically,

to think about how you
shape your question."

Oftentimes, you know, determines
the kind of answer you get.
And so, you know, these are new skills

that I think we're gonna
have to help people learn

but if they're able to
master those skills,

they really benefit from kind
of the collective knowledge

of humanity that's been
scraped and gathered

and distilled through
the generative AI models.
And you have access

to that now in ways that
are very conversational
and you can provide a lot of context

to your question that
maybe get a better answer
than you may get today.

So I think there's so many
ways to use this for tailoring,

for, you know, specific
use cases to help people

that, you know, I think were
just at the beginning of that.

- Well, I'm so excited and I
can't wait to see, you know,

what you and your team
continue to do with that.
And so building on that,

even thinking a little bit
further down the line, you know,
when all is said and done, you know,
how do you want to be remembered

or what do you really wanna
be known for, you know,

in the technology industry,
whether that's spanning both,
you know, public and private sector?
- Yeah, I would say there's two things.

The first one is really
has to do with impact.
For me, I really, again, I like that joy
on someone's else's face.
To me, I get really energized by that.

So how am I able to help
more people take advantage

of technology in a way that
benefits them and helps them,

you know, realize what their
dreams are or assist them
in ways to help them have a better life

or a better opportunity, or
just how do we put technology
to use for us for good?
Right? So that's the first one.
And the second one is, there is a little

of that teaching element
that says, you know,

if I'm not here, how do I
instill the desire or curiosity

for people to not be afraid
of technology, but embrace it
and say, "This is a tool that I can use.
It's for me, it's for my benefit.
And if I learn a few of these things,
it can be really beneficial to me."
So that broad impact and that installation

of curiosity are things
I really wanna make sure
that I have as much as I can be,
affect as many people as possible
with those two things.
- Well, that's amazing

and I think it's so important,
especially, you know,

given your senior level role
that you get to have that level
of influence and use it for good.
So thank you for actually being, you know,

true to that and living
up that purpose, you know,
for really the world to see.

So Dominic, it's been
such a pleasure chatting
with you today and getting a glimpse more

into your world and
your trailblazing career

and can't wait to see what
other innovations, you know,

come out of your organization
and under your leadership.
So thank you for all that you do.
- Awesome. Thank you so much, Sarah.
Appreciate it.
- Thanks.
(upbeat music)
